abstractContent.text: In this paper, we describe Exodus, a joint pilot project of the European Commission's Directorate-General for Translation (DGT) and the European Parliament's Directorate-General for Translation (DG TRAD) which explores the potential of deploying new approaches to machine translation in European institutions.

entities.text: European Parliament's Directorate-General for Translation (DG TRAD)

abstractContent.text: We have participated in the English-to-French track of this year's WMT10 shared translation task using a system trained on data previously extracted from large in-house translation memories.

datasetContent.text: In one of the tasks of the WMT10 human evaluation campaign, people were asked to rank competing translations.
From each 1-through-5 ranking of a set of 5 system outputs, 10 pairwise comparisons are extracted.
Then, for each system, a score is computed that tells how often it was ranked equally or better than the other system.
For our system, this score is 32.35%, meaning it ranked 17th out of 19 systems for English-to-French.
A number of automatic scores were also calculated and appear in.

As the goal behind building our system has been to provide a tool to translators at EU institutions, we have also had it evaluated by two of our colleagues, both: Results of Editing Task ("OK" means "No corrections needed"; "Bad" means "Unable to correct") native speakers of French and working as professional translators of the French Language Unit at the Parliament's DG TRAD.

entities.text: French Language Unit at the Parliament's DG TRAD

datasetContent.text: For this purpose, we had 1742 sentences of in-house documents translated by our system as well as by the rule-based ECMT and the statistics-based Google Translate.
We developed an online evaluation tool based on the one used by the WMT evaluation campaign in the last years where we asked the evaluators to perform three different tasks.
In the first one, they were shown the three automatic translations plus a human reference in random order and asked to rank the four versions relative to each other on a scale from 1 to 5.
The average relative ranks can be seen in.
The second task consisted of post-editing a given translation.
Again, the sentence might come from one of three MT systems, or be a human translation.
The absolute number of items that did not need any corrections, had to be edited, or were impossible to correct are shown in.
For the third and last task, only translations of our own system were displayed.

Here, the evaluators should simply assign them to one of four quality categories as proposed by, and additionally tick boxes standing for the presence of 13 different types of errors in the sentence concerning word order, punctuation, or different types of syntactic/semantic problems.
A total of 150 segments were judged.
For the categorization results, see.
On aside note, the Portuguese Language Department also performed a manual evaluation) which involved 14 of their managers and translators, comparing their Moses-based system to   ECMT and Google.
shows how many people considered Moses better, similar, or worse compared to ECMT and Google, respectively.

Moses-based SMT did well in fields where ECMT is systematically used (e.g. Justice and Home Affairs and Trade) and showed a big improvement over ECMT in terminology-intensive domains (e.g. Fisheries).
As of early 2009, more than half of their translators (58%) now already use ECMT systematically in production, i.e. for all English and French originals.
85% use it for specific language combinations or for certain domains only.
On a voluntary basis, they have been replacing ECMT with Moses-based SMT for the translation of day-to-day incoming documents.

Over a three-month period, more than 2500 pages have been translated in this manner, and the translators of the Portuguese department declared themselves ready to switch over to an SMT system as soon as it should become available.
